DOC.HEAD: Famous Knife Maker Dead at 80
DOC.TEXT: Walter Doane ``Bo'' Randall, renowned as one of the world's best knife makers, is dead at age 80. Randall, who began hand-crafting hunting knives half a century ago as a hobby, had an eight-man factory in Orlando that turned out knives favored by the Army's Special Forces and military men and civilians in many countries. Randall knives are displayed in the Smithsonian Institution and the Museum of Special Warfare at Fort Bragg, N.C. Each Randall blade is made of ``the best high-carbon steel, forged, ground, tempered and fitted to the hilt entirely by hand,'' said Harper's Magazine years ago. ``Although the demand is heavy _ his shop often has to backlog orders for more than a year _ nobody has ever tried to compete with him by mass-production methods.'' The knife-collector's bible, American Knives, referred to Randall as the world's greatest blade maker. Randall, born in Cincinnati, died Monday. Survivors include his wife Ruth, a son, two daughters, a brother and 10 grandchildren.
